frontmatter.title: Your First Go Program
frontmatter.description: Write your first Go program and understand the basic structure of Go code.

pageProps.content:
# Your First Go Program This lab will guide you through writing your first Go program and understanding the basic structure of Go code. ## Learning Objectives By the end of this lab, you will be able to: - Set up a Go development environment - Create and run a simple Go program - Understand the basic structure of a Go program - Use the `fmt` package for output ## Introduction Go (or Golang) is a statically typed, compiled programming language designed at Google. It's known for its simplicity, efficiency, and built-in concurrency features. In this lab, we'll write our first Go program and explore the basic structure of Go code. ## Setup First, make sure you have Go installed on your system. You can check by running: go version If Go is not installed, follow the instructions on the [official Go website](https://golang.org/doc/install). Create a new directory for your project: mkdir hello-world cd hello-world Initialize a new Go module: go mod init example.com/hello-world This creates a `go.mod` file that defines your module and its dependencies. ## Writing Your First Go Program Create a new file called `main.go` with the following content: ```go package main import "fmt" func main() { fmt.Println("Hello, Go!") } ``` Let's break down this code:
  • `package main`: Every Go file starts with a package declaration. The `main` package is special - it defines an executable program rather than a library.
  • `import "fmt"`: This imports the `fmt` package, which contains functions for formatted I/O.
  • `func main()`: The `main` function is the entry point of your program. When you run your program, execution starts here.
  • `fmt.Println("Hello, Go!")`: This calls the `Println` function from the `fmt` package to print text to the console.
 Run your program using the `go run` command: go run main.go You should see the output: Hello, Go! Congratulations! You've just written and run your first Go program. ## Building Your Program The `go run` command compiles and runs your program in one step. To build an executable file that you can run later, use the `go build` command: go build This creates an executable file named after your module (in this case, `hello-world` or `hello-world.exe` on Windows). Run the executable: ./hello-world # On Unix-like systems hello-world.exe # On Windows You should see the same output as before: Hello, Go! ## Adding More Functionality Let's modify our program to make it more interactive. Update `main.go` with the following code: ```go package main import ( "fmt" "time" ) func main() { name := "Gopher" currentTime := time.Now() fmt.Println("Hello,", name + "!") fmt.Println("The current time is:", currentTime.Format("15:04:05")) // Using Printf for formatted output fmt.Printf("Today is %s, %d %s %d\n", currentTime.Weekday(), currentTime.Day(), currentTime.Month(), currentTime.Year()) } ``` This enhanced program:
  • Imports the `time` package to work with dates and times
  • Uses variables to store a name and the current time
  • Demonstrates string concatenation with the `+` operator
  • Uses `Printf` for formatted output with placeholders
 Run your enhanced program: go run main.go You should see output similar to this (with the current date and time): Hello, Gopher! The current time is: 14:30:45 Today is Monday, 15 May 2023 ## Exercises Now it's your turn to practice what you've learned. Complete the following exercises: ### Exercise 1: Personalize the greeting Modify the program to ask for the user's name and then greet them.
Solution ```go package main import ( "bufio" "fmt" "os" "strings" "time" ) func main() { // Create a reader to read from standard input reader := bufio.NewReader(os.Stdin) // Prompt for name fmt.Print("Enter your name: ") // Read the input until a newline name, _ := reader.ReadString('\n') // Trim whitespace (including the newline) name = strings.TrimSpace(name) // Get current time currentTime := time.Now() // Greet the user fmt.Println("Hello,", name + "!") fmt.Println("The current time is:", currentTime.Format("15:04:05")) // Using Printf for formatted output fmt.Printf("Today is %s, %d %s %d\n", currentTime.Weekday(), currentTime.Day(), currentTime.Month(), currentTime.Year()) } ```
### Exercise 2: Add a custom greeting based on the time of day Extend the program to provide a different greeting based on the time of day (morning, afternoon, evening).
Solution ```go package main import ( "bufio" "fmt" "os" "strings" "time" ) func main() { // Create a reader to read from standard input reader := bufio.NewReader(os.Stdin) // Prompt for name fmt.Print("Enter your name: ") // Read the input until a newline name, _ := reader.ReadString('\n') // Trim whitespace (including the newline) name = strings.TrimSpace(name) // Get current time currentTime := time.Now() hour := currentTime.Hour() // Determine greeting based on time of day var greeting string if hour < 12 { greeting = "Good morning" } else if hour < 18 { greeting = "Good afternoon" } else { greeting = "Good evening" } // Greet the user fmt.Printf("%s, %s!\n", greeting, name) fmt.Println("The current time is:", currentTime.Format("15:04:05")) // Using Printf for formatted output fmt.Printf("Today is %s, %d %s %d\n", currentTime.Weekday(), currentTime.Day(), currentTime.Month(), currentTime.Year()) } ```
## Challenge (Optional) For an extra challenge, try to implement a program that: - Asks the user for their birth year - Calculates and displays their age - Tells them if it's their birthday today
Solution ```go package main import ( "bufio" "fmt" "os" "strconv" "strings" "time" ) func main() { reader := bufio.NewReader(os.Stdin) // Get current time currentTime := time.Now() currentYear := currentTime.Year() // Prompt for birth year fmt.Print("Enter your birth year: ") birthYearStr, _ := reader.ReadString('\n') birthYearStr = strings.TrimSpace(birthYearStr) // Convert string to integer birthYear, err := strconv.Atoi(birthYearStr) if err != nil { fmt.Println("Invalid year. Please enter a valid number.") return } // Calculate age age := currentYear - birthYear // Display age fmt.Printf("You are approximately %d years old.\n", age) // Prompt for birth month and day fmt.Print("Enter your birth month (1-12): ") birthMonthStr, _ := reader.ReadString('\n') birthMonthStr = strings.TrimSpace(birthMonthStr) fmt.Print("Enter your birth day (1-31): ") birthDayStr, _ := reader.ReadString('\n') birthDayStr = strings.TrimSpace(birthDayStr) // Convert to integers birthMonth, err1 := strconv.Atoi(birthMonthStr) birthDay, err2 := strconv.Atoi(birthDayStr) if err1 != nil || err2 != nil || birthMonth < 1 || birthMonth > 12 || birthDay < 1 || birthDay > 31 { fmt.Println("Invalid date. Skipping birthday check.") return } // Check if today is their birthday if currentTime.Month() == time.Month(birthMonth) && currentTime.Day() == birthDay { fmt.Println("ðŸŽ‰ Happy Birthday! ðŸŽ‚") } else { fmt.Println("Today is not your birthday.") } } ```
## Summary In this lab, you learned: - How to set up a Go development environment - The basic structure of a Go program - How to create, build, and run Go code - How to use the `fmt` package for output - How to work with variables and the `time` package ## Next Steps Now that you've completed this lab, you can: - Move on to the next lab: [Go Data Types and Variables](/labs/go-data-types-and-variables) - Explore more about Go's standard library - Practice by writing more simple Go programs ## Additional Resources - [Official Go Documentation](https://golang.org/doc/) - [Go by Example: Hello World](https://gobyexample.com/hello-world) - [A Tour of Go](https://tour.golang.org/welcome/1)
